## You will learn in this session

* how to estimate heritability
* how to perform phylogenetic regressions
* how to perform meta-analyses

# Studying genetic variation using LMM

## The animal model

Nothing but a simple LMM:

$$ y_i = \mu + a_i + e_i$$

with:

* $\mu$ the population mean
* $a_i$ the breeding value (i.e. the effects of the $i$'s genotype relative to $\mu$)
* $e_i$ a residual term.

<br>

The variance of the breeding values is the additive genetic variance $V_\text{A}$.

The additive genetic covariance between two individuals = $\text{A}V_\text{A}$, where $\text{A}$ is the relatedness matrix.

## Building the matrix A

```{r, message = FALSE}
tail(Gryphon$pedigree)
library(nadiv)
A <- as(makeA(Gryphon$pedigree), "matrix")
colnames(A) <- rownames(A) <- Gryphon$pedigree$ID
A[1305:1309, 1296:1309]
```

## Fitting a simple Animal Model

```{r animal model, message=FALSE}
library(spaMM)
system.time(mod1 <- fitme(BWT ~ 1 + corrMatrix(1|ID), corrMatrix = A, data = Gryphon$data, method = "REML"))
(h2 <- as.numeric(mod1$lambda / (mod1$lambda + mod1$phi)))
```

<br>

So `r round(100*h2,1)` % of the variation in birth weight is due to inheritance!


## Fitting a more complex Animal Model

```{r animal model 2, message=FALSE}
Gryphon$data$sex    <- factor(Gryphon$data$SEX)
Gryphon$data$year   <- factor(Gryphon$data$BYEAR)
Gryphon$data$mother <- factor(Gryphon$data$MOTHER)

system.time(
  fit2 <- fitme(BWT ~ sex + (1|year) + (1|mother) + corrMatrix(1|ID), corrMatrix = A,
                data = Gryphon$data, method = "REML")
)

h2 <- as.numeric(fit2$lambda[3] / (sum(fit2$lambda) + fit2$phi)) ## ID
m2 <- as.numeric(fit2$lambda[2] / (sum(fit2$lambda) + fit2$phi)) ## mother

round(c("heritability (without maternal effect)" = h2, "maternal effect" = m2), 3)
```


## Predicting the breeding values ($a_i$)

```{r, fig.height=3.5, fig.width=4}
curve(dnorm(x, sd = sqrt(as.numeric(fit2$lambda[3]))), from = -3, to = 3, las = 1,
      ylab = "pdf", xlab = "predicted breeding value")
BLUPs <- ranef(fit2)$"corrMatrix(1 | ID)"
points(dnorm(BLUPs, sd = sqrt(as.numeric(fit2$lambda[3]))) ~ BLUPs, col = "blue", type = "h", lwd = 0.1)
```

Never do statistics on BLUPs! Neglecting the uncertainty associated to these predictions is wrong.

Since BLUPs are here not added to fitted values, REML fit is the proper way to get them!

## Predicting the breeding values ($a_i$)

```{r}
plot(BLUPs ~ scale(fit2$data$BWT), ylab = "Predicted breeding values", xlab = "Scaled phenotypic values")
```


# Phylogenetic regressions


## The ```ade4::carni70``` dataset

```{r}
library(ade4)
data(carni70)
carni70$tab
```


## The phylogeny

```{r}
library(ape)
tree <- read.tree(text = carni70$tre)
plot(tree, cex = 0.3)
```


## Turning a tree into a correlation matrix

```{r}
(corrM <- vcv(tree, model = "Brownian", corr = TRUE))
```


## Fitting the phylogenetic regression model

```{r}
carni70$tab$sp <- factor(rownames(corrM))
(fit_carni <- fitme(range ~ size + corrMatrix(1|sp), corrMatrix = corrM, data = carni70$tab))
```


## Testing the fixed effects

Here we test the effect of the body size on the geographic range of the species accounting for the phylogeny:

```{r}
fit_carni_no_size <- fitme(range ~ 1 + corrMatrix(1|sp), corrMatrix = corrM, data = carni70$tab)
anova(fit_carni, fit_carni_no_size)
```

Note: **{spaMM}** does not allow (out-of-the-box) for using a correlation function that is dependent on a parameter (unless such correlation is implemented in **{spaMM}**). So we cannot use all the possibilites offered by **{ape}**.


## Comparison with the traditional **{gls}** fit

```{r, message = FALSE}
library(nlme)
rownames(carni70$tab) <- rownames(corrM)
(fit_carni2 <- gls(range ~ size, correlation = corBrownian(1, phy = tree), method = "ML", data = carni70$tab))
```

A key benefit of using a proper (G)LMM instead of the Generalized Least Squares is that we could also consider other random effects and model a non gaussian response (GLMM).
The function ```fitme()``` does that, but ```gls()``` cannot.


## Comparison with the traditional **{gls}** fit

```{r}
fit_carni2_no_size <- gls(range ~ 1, correlation = corBrownian(1, tree), method = "ML", data = carni70$tab)
anova(fit_carni2, fit_carni2_no_size)
```

<br>

Note: differences between LMM and GLS are expected.

# Meta-analyses

## Example: The ```metafor::dat.bcg``` dataset

Studies on the effectiveness of the BCG vaccine against Tuberculosis

```{r, message = FALSE}
library(metafor)
dat.bcg
```


## We compute an effect size

 Let's compute the relative risks and associated sampling variances:
```{r}
dat.bcg$RR  <- with(dat.bcg, log((tpos/(tpos + tneg)) / (cpos/(cpos + cneg))))
dat.bcg$sampling.var <- with(dat.bcg, 1/tpos - 1/tneg + 1/cpos - 1/cneg)
dat.bcg
```


## We fit the model with **{metafor}**

```{r}
(fit <- rma(yi = RR ~ factor(alloc) + year + ablat, vi = sampling.var, data = dat.bcg, method = "REML"))
```


## We fit the model with **{spaMM}**

```{r}
dat.bcg$study <- factor(dat.bcg$trial)
(fit_spaMM <- fitme(RR ~ factor(alloc) + year + ablat + (1|study), data = dat.bcg,
                    fixed = list(phi = dat.bcg$sampling.var), method = "REML"))
```


## Comparing outputs

```{r}
round(c(tau2_metafor = fit$tau2, lambda_spaMM = fit_spaMM$lambda[[1]]), 4)  ## heterogeneity between studies

fit_spaMMRE <- fitme(RR ~ 1 + (1|study), data = dat.bcg,
                     fixed = list(phi = dat.bcg$sampling.var), method = "REML")

R2_spaMM <- 100 * (fit_spaMMRE$lambda[[1]] - fit_spaMM$lambda[[1]]) / fit_spaMMRE$lambda[[1]]
round(c(R2_metafor = fit$R2, R2_spaMM = R2_spaMM), 4)  ## amount of heterogeneity accounted for by fixed effects
```

Conclusion: if you know a general and flexible package like **{spaMM}** you can reproduce what many specialised packages do. Here, we use **{spaMM}** to perform a meta-analysis exactly as the specialised package **{metafor}** does it. **{spaMM}** can consider complexities that **{metafor}** cannot handle, but the reverse is also true.


## Comparing outputs (more)

```{r}
c(fit$I2, fit$H2, fit$QE) ## from metafor, see ?print.rma.uni for details

get_meta_metrics <- function(model, vi) {
  wi <- 1/vi  ## weights = inverse of sampling variance
  k <- length(model$ranef)  ## number of groups in random term (here number of studies)
  p <- length(model$fixef)  ## number of fixed effect parameters
  W <- diag(wi, nrow = k, ncol = k)  ## matrix of weights
  X <- as.matrix(as.data.frame(model$X.pv))  ## design matrix
  stXWX <- solve(t(X) %*% W %*% X)  ## weighted vcov of estimates
  P <- W - W %*% X %*% stXWX %*% crossprod(X, W)  ## weighted vcov of ??
  vi.avg <- (k - p) / sum(diag(P))
  I2 <- as.numeric(100 * model$lambda / (vi.avg + model$lambda) )
  H2 <- as.numeric((vi.avg + model$lambda) / vi.avg)
  QE <- max(0, c(crossprod(model$y, P) %*% model$y))
  return(c(I2 = I2, H2 = H2, QE = QE, vi.avg = vi.avg))
}

get_meta_metrics(fit_spaMM, dat.bcg$sampling.var) ## add vi.avg: weighted mean within study sampling variance
```


## Nice plots with **{metafor}**

```{r, fig.width = 6, fig.height = 5.5}
metafor::plot.rma.uni(fit)  ## or just plot(fit)
```


## Can we do abstraction of fixed effects?

```{r}
fit_spaMM2    <- fitme(RR ~ factor(alloc) + year + ablat + (1|study), data = dat.bcg,
                       fixed = list(phi = dat.bcg$sampling.var))
fit_spaMM2_H0 <- fitme(RR ~ 1 + (1|study), data = dat.bcg, fixed = list(phi = dat.bcg$sampling.var))
anova(fit_spaMM2, fit_spaMM2_H0)
```


## Can we do abstraction of fixed effects?

```{r test for metafor, results = "hide"}
res.boot <- anova(fit_spaMM2, fit_spaMM2_H0, boot.repl = 1000, fit_env = list(dat.bcg = dat.bcg))
```

```{r, cache = FALSE}
res.boot
```

Yes we can! (but only just)


## Can we do abstraction of fixed effects?

```{r}
(fit2 <- rma(yi = RR ~ factor(alloc) + year + ablat, vi = sampling.var, data = dat.bcg, method = "ML"))
```


## Can we do abstraction of fixed effects?

```{r}
(fit3 <- rma(yi = RR ~ factor(alloc) + year + ablat, vi = sampling.var, data = dat.bcg, method = "ML",
             test = "knha"))
```


## Does vaccination work?

```{r}
fit_spaMM3    <- fitme(RR ~ 1 + (1|study), data = dat.bcg, fixed = list(phi = dat.bcg$sampling.var))
fit_spaMM3_H0 <- fitme(RR ~ 0 + (1|study), data = dat.bcg, fixed = list(phi = dat.bcg$sampling.var))
anova(fit_spaMM3, fit_spaMM3_H0)
```


## Does vaccination work?

```{r test for metafor 2, results = "hide"}
res.boot2 <- anova(fit_spaMM3, fit_spaMM3_H0, boot.repl = 1000, fit_env = list(dat.bcg = dat.bcg))
```

```{r, cache = FALSE}
res.boot2
```

Yes it does!


## Does vaccination work?

```{r}
fit_spaMM3$fixef
get_intervals(fit_spaMM3, re.form = NA, intervals = "predVar")[1, ]
```


## Does vaccination work?

```{r}
(fit4 <- rma(yi = RR ~ 1, vi = sampling.var, data = dat.bcg, method = "ML"))
```


## Does vaccination work?

```{r}
forest(fit4)
```
